topic.title: Is using Tor Browser really safer on ZeroNet ?
topic.body:
I just checked and apparently ZeroNet can't work without JavaScript so NoScript has to be disabled, and I doubt there is any use for HTTPS Everywhere for ZeroNet considering the server is on localhost. So basically, is having a common user agent for Tor service users worth letting every single script enabled instead of, say, having a Waterfox with privacy settings activated along with a few extensions to block specific tracking stuff. Or, considering it's unwise to install extensions on Tor Browser because that would make your track easy to identify, why not just install these extensions to block specific stuff on Tor Browser considering you shouldn't worry about specific method to find out who you are when scripts are enabled anyways ? 

TL;DR, is using Tor Browser with Tor enabled really important on ZeroNet / good enough to feel safe ?

topic.title: It would seem Firefox doesn't handle ES6 classes anymore ?
topic.body:
Here's the zite I'm talking about: 

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1DoxbinuaNEdDagSpPmbCEkKHB1FW9RzzJ/

If you test it on Chrome / Chromium ( I tested it on Brave and Dissenter ), it works perfectly. However, if you test it on Firefox ( I tested it on Tor Browser, Waterfox and Firefox, the last two are fresh installs ), nothing works anymore. You can't select an user, nothing. Now if I go in the console, it would seem Firefox doesn't handle ES6 Classes, which is weird because it should be supporting them since the version 45 released in 2016: 

https://caniuse.com/#feat=es6-class

Now here are my two problems: 

1. ZeroChat uses ES6 Classes, infact the Zite I gave you is built using ZeroChat's base code, meaning that if my assumption is right, the ONLY tutorial we have to create a Zite doesn't work for Firefox "anymore". 

2. How does one fix this, for example with the Zite I gave ? Or is maybe the error coming from somewhere else ? But there again, I doubt it's coming from the code, since Chromium browsers handle it perfectly.

1557421253_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBj.body:
> [pexo](#comment_85_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): Yes, not only do you feel more safe, you actually are. The TBB forces website/zite traffic through the Tor network. Zites on zeronet can make requests to clearnet servers(due to the way js is build) and as soon as a zite makes connection to any clearnet site, that site knows your ip address and (depending on implementation) also maybe that you came from zeronet, if the referrer was set(for example to 127.0.0.1:43110). ZeroID, for example, sends the data that needs to be signed to a server that knows the zeroID signing key. That server is a clearnet server and if you didn't use the TBB that server now knows your ip. ZeroBoard was made like this as well.Also the TBB does a lot of stuff behind the scenes to make tracking you as hard as possible.   [...]

Thanks for all the information. I suppose using the Tor Browser and hoping ZeroNet devs work on fixing some stuff about it is the way to go then.

> [pexo](#comment_106_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): You can also use CHECK in the tables-section for really fine grained control over what is accepted into the db as id.For example this: text NOT NULL UNIQUE CHECK(tag_ID NOT GLOB '*[^a-z^A-Z^0-9]*' AND length(tag_ID) BETWEEN 1 AND 43 ) is what I use in UFTS to check tagIDs(which are base62 encoded 256-bit blake hashes) before they are added to the db. Any tag_ID that doesn't fit this criteria will not be added to anyone's database.

Not really needed for this example though since we can see in Data.json that we try to add "1", right ? Nice to know for security though.

> [pexo](#comment_107_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): Nevermind, I'm blind. Your history table doesn't have a ["json_id", "INTEGER REFERENCES json (json_id)"]-row. That's the reason why it doesn't work. The INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT thing I mentioned was related to an strange issue I had in the past.

That was an old version I mistakenly shared instead of the most recent one that I had already fixed. The problem ended up being that what I wanted to do, while it made sense, wasn't supported yet. The idea was to have this in my data.json: 

temp: [
    1, 
    2
]

But it isn't possible yet, as in it isn't supported by ZN. Ended up having to rework the DBSchema and now the first half of the Zite in question is working. I'm gonna create another Zite ( It's a 2-Zite project ) and then finish that one and I'll be able to publish my work eh eh. Thanks for the help you gave me so far.

> [pexo](#comment_108_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): Oh, okay. Glad it worked out anyway.By the way, aside from json_id, keep away from the references-keyword in dbschema.json. [...]

> [pexo](#comment_109_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): I have some ideas, but I'm not sure why exactly, but on the py3 version the database bricks in some cases and you need to delete it, and then restart the whole client in order for your zite to work again. Also since you can't really control the order tables get generated(it's alphabetic only most of the time) certain entries will fail to be added and zeronet(probably not expecting the sqlite error) will get into the bricked state I've written above. The same happens, if you add a column that depends on two different users. Over all a bad time, if you ask me.
